Another less obvious view would be that code is the surface of the digital. As the field that facilitates the calculations on the processor through an informational layer. Placing the editor and the quotes and images in that perspective means that it sits closer to the

*surface of the digital, as the field that facilitates the calculations on the processor through an informational layer. Placing the editor and the quotes and images in that perspective means that it sits closer to the threshold of the digital, where the noise of the machine is reduced to the gentle hum of the processor. From here, the code becomes the interface to the digital, a bridge between the user and the machine. The editor's keys become the fingers of the user, typing out the instructions for the machine to follow.*
